results.title: Clifton Collins Jr. Hopes ‘Jockey’ Makes a Familiar Face a Familiar Name, Too
results.abstract: You know the actor from countless TV shows, but after immersive preparation for a rare leading role, he appears headed for a breakthrough.

multimedia.caption: “I’ve had other leading roles, just not like this,” said Clifton Collins Jr., who’s been winning accolades for his turn as an aging rider.
multimedia.copyright: Carlos Jaramillo for The New York Times

results.title: Maggie Gyllenhaal Has Dangerous Ideas About Directing
results.abstract: Is there such a thing as a women’s film or women’s filmmaking? With “The Lost Daughter,” she says the answer is yes.

multimedia.caption: Movies don’t often explore the frustrations of motherhood, Gyllenhaal said, because “we’re all like, I don’t want my mother to have been ambivalent.”
multimedia.copyright: Daniel Arnold for The New York Times

results.title: In Mexico, Women Directors Take the Lead
results.abstract: After decades of struggling for the recognition long granted their male peers, female filmmakers in Mexico are setting the industry ablaze.

multimedia.caption: Tatiana Huezo made the Oscar shortlist for best international feature for “Prayers for the Stolen.”

results.title: ‘Jockey’ Review: Hit Hard and Still Riding
results.abstract: In this plaintive drama, Clifton Collins Jr. plays a veteran jockey who has had one too many falls and is fast aging out of his profession.

multimedia.caption: Molly Parker and Clifton Collins Jr. in “Jockey,” from the director Clint Bentley.

results.title: ‘The Lost Daughter’ Review: The Parent Trap
results.abstract: This dreamy thriller follows an academic with a mysterious past who heads to a beach vacation on the Greek islands.

multimedia.caption: Dakota Johnson, left, and Olivia Colman in “The Lost Daughter,” Maggie Gyllenhaal’s feature directorial debut.

results.title: ‘Pariah’ at 10: When Black Lesbian Characters Had the Spotlight
results.abstract: The Dee Rees drama made waves but studios largely returned to business as usual. A new crop of filmmakers sees signs of hope.

multimedia.caption: Aasha Davis, left, and Adepero Oduye in “Pariah.” The film was made for less than $500,000.

results.title: How Nicole Kidman Learned to Love Playing Lucille Ball
results.abstract: A career of dramas like “The Hours” and “Big Little Lies” was not enough to help Kidman portray the “I Love Lucy” star in “Being the Ricardos.” As she put it, “Funny’s hard.”

multimedia.caption: When it comes to comedies, “I don’t get cast in them,” Nicole Kidman said. That might be the result of a career spent in dramas or “it might be my personality, too.”
multimedia.copyright: Jody Rogac for The New York Times

results.title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: Our newest picks include a good cop-bad cop revenge thriller starring Donnie Yen, a high-tech animated take on Hansel and Gretel, and more.

multimedia.caption: Donnie Yen in a scene from “Raging Fire,” directed by Benny Chan.

results.title: ‘Poupelle of Chimney Town’ Review: Seeking Refuse
results.abstract: In this anime feature, a lonely boy strikes up a friendship with a trash creature and searches for stars in a polluted sky.

multimedia.caption: Poupelle (voiced by Tony Hale), left, and Lubicchi (voiced by Antonio Raul Corbo) in “Poupelle of Chimney Town,” directed by Yusuke Hirota.

results.title: Deaths in 2021: Headline Names Against the Backdrop of Pandemic
results.abstract: Aaron, Sondheim, Dole and Didion. But the loss of Colin Powell from the virus spoke most directly to the moment the world is in.

multimedia.copyright: Didion: Henry Clarke/Condé Nast/Shutterstock; Powell: Kenneth Lambert/AP; Madden: via Associated Press; Sondheim: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times; Tyson: Kevin Winter/Getty Images; Allard: Jens Schwarz/laif/Redux

results.title: Our Favorite Arts Photos of 2021
results.abstract: These are the pictures that defined an unpredictable year across the worlds of art, music, dance and performance.
results.byline: By Laura O’Neill, Jolie Ruben and Jessie Wender

multimedia.caption: After 15 months of darkness, live music returned. In New York, Foo Fighters reopened Madison Square Garden.
multimedia.copyright: Photograph by Tim Barber for The New York Times

results.title: At Home This New Year’s Eve (Unexpectedly)? Here’s What to Watch.
results.abstract: In case the Omicron spike has scrapped your plans, these binge watches, live broadcasts and double features will bring the party to you.
des_facet: Dick Clark's New Year's Rockin' Eve With Ryan Seacrest (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: Regina Voce in the singing competition “Queen of the Universe” on Paramount+.

results.title: Stream These 9 Titles Before They Leave Netflix in January
results.abstract: The turnover is a little lighter this month for U.S. subscribers, but there are still a bunch of great movies and TV shows worth catching.

multimedia.caption: Sean Penn, left, and Kevin Bacon in “Mystic River” (2003).

results.title: For Pop Music, 2021 Was the Year of the Deep Dive
results.abstract: Documentaries brought us closer to musicians this year, and it wasn’t always pretty.
des_facet: Summer of Soul (... Or, When the Revolution Could Not Be Televised) (Movie)
Billie Eilish: The World's a Little Blurry (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Billie Eilish’s whirlwind career — at 16, 17 and 18 years old — is chronicled in R.J. Cutler’s “The World’s a Little Blurry.”

results.title: Mike Faist Tries to Keep His Cool as Riff in ‘West Side Story’
results.abstract: The actor, a star of Broadway musicals like “Dear Evan Hansen,” talks about playing the leader of the Jets in Steven Spielberg’s remake.

multimedia.caption: Mike Faist was first asked to read for the part of Tony. When he was called back to read for Riff and found it a good fit, he realized, “Oh crap. Now I have to do it.”
multimedia.copyright: Erik Carter for The New York Times

results.title: Jean-Marc Vallée, Director of ‘Dallas Buyers Club,’ Dies at 58
results.abstract: Known for his naturalistic approach, the Canadian-born filmmaker transformed true stories into acclaimed dramas.

multimedia.caption: The filmmaker Jean-Marc Vallée in 2015. His “Dallas Buyers Club” won three Oscars.

results.title: Hollywood Tests the Limit of Marquee Names a Single Film Can Hold
results.abstract: Boldface names have always mattered at the movies, but a number of recent casts have been full of them. That hasn’t always helped at the box office.

multimedia.caption: Marketing for “Don’t Look Up” has emphasized its star-studded cast, including Leonardo DiCaprio and Jennifer Lawrence.
multimedia.copyright: Mark Abramson for The New York Times

results.title: Five Joan Didion Movies You Can Stream Right Now
results.abstract: The writer, working with her husband, John Gregory Dunne, saw Hollywood as a way to make cash to support her art. It did and didn’t work out.
des_facet: Joan Didion: The Center Will Not Hold (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Barbra Streisand and Kris Kristofferson in "A Star Is Born" (1976).

results.title: Five Science-Fiction Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: This month’s picks include apocalyptic K-pop and a parallel-dimension thriller.

multimedia.caption: Nora Arnezeder in “The Colony,” directed by Tim Fehlbaum.

results.title: What Is ‘West Side Story’ Without Jerome Robbins? Chatty.
results.abstract: Justin Peck takes over choreographic duties in the Steven Spielberg adaptation of the 1957 musical in which words, not bodies, rule the screen.

multimedia.caption: David Alvarez, center, plays Bernardo in Steven Spielberg’s new movie, with choreography by Justin Peck.

results.title: Dave Draper, Bodybuilding’s ‘Blond Bomber,’ Dies at 79
results.abstract: After being named Mr. America, Mr. Universe and Mr. World, he left competitive bodybuilding in 1970. But he kept lifting weights until a year before he died.

multimedia.caption: Dave Draper at the 1965 Mr. America competition. He won that and two other major bodybuilding titles before dropping out of competition at age 28.

results.title: ‘Don’t Look Up’ Review: Tick, Tick, Kablooey
results.abstract: Adam McKay wants you to know that it’s the end of the world and you should absolutely, unequivocally not feel fine. (But do laugh.)

multimedia.caption: Oh, no: Jennifer Lawrence plays a grad student who spots a comet that is hurtling toward Earth.

results.title: ‘A Journal for Jordan’ Review: Reflections on Love Built and Lost
results.abstract: The actors Michael B. Jordan and Chanté Adams bring a compelling chemistry to the screen as opposites who fall for each other.
des_facet: A Journal for Jordan: A Story of Love and Honor (Book)

multimedia.caption: Michael B. Jordan as Charles Monroe King and Chanté Adams as Dana Canedy in “A Journal for Jordan.”

results.title: ‘Parallel Mothers’ Review: Almodóvar’s Brutal, Beautiful World
results.abstract: The Spanish director finally confronts the legacy of his country’s political violence in his new film, starring Penélope Cruz and Milena Smit.

multimedia.caption: Penélope Cruz, left, and Milena Smit in “Parallel Mothers.”

results.title: ‘American Underdog’ Review: A Football Fairy Tale
results.abstract: Zachary Levi plays the N.F.L. star Kurt Warner in this biopic. It’s a wan parable about love and hard work.

multimedia.caption: Anna Paquin and Zachary Levi in “American Underdog.”

results.title: ‘Memoria’ Review: In Search of Lost Time
results.abstract: Tilda Swinton stars in Apichatpong Weerasethakul’s elusive and enchanting new film, set in Colombia.

multimedia.caption: In “Memoria,” Tilda Swinton plays a British expatriate in Colombia whose perceptions come into question during this startling movie.

results.title: ‘Dead Man’s Switch: A Crypto Mystery’ Review: A Staggering Scam?
results.abstract: A new documentary tries to unpack how $200 million went unaccounted for after the Canadian cryptocurrency entrepreneur Gerald W. Cotten died.
des_facet: Dead Man's Switch: A Crypto Mystery (Movie)

multimedia.caption: A recreated scene in the Sheona McDonald documentary “Dead Man’s Switch: A Crypto Mystery.”

results.title: The Artists We Lost in 2021, in Their Words
results.abstract: Some artists held the spotlight for generations. Others left us lamenting careers cut short. Here is a tribute to those we lost this year.

multimedia.copyright: Demetrius Freeman for The New York Times

results.title: TikTok Made Them Famous. Figuring Out What’s Next Is Tough.
results.abstract: This year, the app’s biggest stars — Charli and Dixie D’Amelio, Noah Beck, Addison Rae and others — leapt from the phone screen to other platforms in the pop culture universe, with mixed results.

multimedia.caption: This year TikTok stars tried their hands at Hulu shows, streaming series and music careers.

results.title: ‘Tragedy of Macbeth’ Review: The Thane, Insane, Slays Mainly in Dunsinane
results.abstract: Denzel Washington and Frances McDormand play a toxic power couple in Joel Coen’s crackling adaptation of Shakespeare’s Scottish play.

multimedia.caption: Denzel Washington in “The Tragedy of Macbeth.” His trajectory from weary soldier to raving, self-immolating maniac is astonishing to behold.

results.title: Peter Dinklage on ‘Cyrano’ and Life After ‘Game of Thrones’
results.abstract: The actor is happy to upend 100 years of clichés by playing the romantic lead. It’s a liberating change after the series became his life.

multimedia.caption: “I was raised Irish Catholic, so I totally feel unworthy of everything,” Peter Dinklage said. “That’s what hopefully this movie is speaking to, that unworthiness we all go through.”
multimedia.copyright: Justin J Wee for The New York Times

results.title: ‘Sing 2’ Review: Taking the Show on the Road
results.abstract: The amateur ensemble is back, this time in animal Las Vegas.

multimedia.caption: Some of the stars of the show in the movie “Sing 2.”

results.title: ‘The Matrix Resurrections’ Review: Slipping Through Dreamland (Again)
results.abstract: Keanu Reeves plunges down the rabbit hole once more in this familiar-seeming mind-game movie, the fourth in the series.

multimedia.caption: Carrie-Anne Moss and Keanu Reeves in “The Matrix Resurrections.”

results.title: ‘The Velvet Queen’ Review: Searching for an Elusive Leopard
results.abstract: The documentary follows the photographer Vincent Munier and the writer Sylvain Tesson on a mission to catch a glimpse of a rare snow leopard in Tibet.

multimedia.caption: The photographer Vincent Munier and the writer Sylvain Tesson are searching for snow leopards in “The Velvet Queen.”
